Morphology-performance relation of (Co)MoS2 catalysts in the hydrodesulfurization of FCC gasoline Cen Zhang a b Ping Li a Xinyi Liu a b Tiefeng Liu a Zongxuan Jiang a ⁎ Can Li a ⁎ 1 a State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian, 116023, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road Dalian 116023 China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 http://www.canli.dicp.ac.cn Graphical abstract The morphology-performance relation is of great importance for designing a catalyst with high performance in the selective hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) gasoline. Herein, we report a simple one-pot hydrothermal method to prepare the unsupported MoS2 catalysts with controlled morphology by adjusting the pH values and using different precursors. It is found that smaller MoS2 crystallites are produced when the pH value decreases in the synthetic process. With the increased MoS2 crystallite size, the HDS selectivity factor (SF) increases from 1.46 to 1.52 for non-promoted MoS2 catalysts, and from 13.96 to 19.69 for Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts. On the other hand, for MoS2 catalysts with similar stacking, the MoS2 with longer slab length exhibits improved HDS selectivity (SF from 2.90 to 2.99). These results confirm that the slab length instead of the stacking for MoS2 particles is more important to influence the HDS selectivity. Due to the fact that the corner sites could catalyze both HDS and HYD reactions while edge sites only catalyze the HDS reaction, thus increasing the edge/corner ratio by preparing (Co)MoS2 catalysts with longer MoS2 slab length is an efficient way to improve the selectivity in the selective HDS of FCC gasoline. Keywords Unsupported (Co)MoS2 Hydrothermal Morphology control FCC gasoline Selective hydrodesulfurization 1 Introduction To meet the increasingly stringent environmental legislation, it is necessary to control the sulfur content in the gasoline. The challenge facing the production of commercial gasoline is hydrotreating of fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) gasoline which is one of the main components of blending gasoline. However, hydrotreating of FCC gasoline results in inevitable octane number loss because of the hydrogenation (HYD) of olefins with high octane number [1]. Therefore, being able to selectively remove the sulfur-containing compounds from FCC gasoline with minimal olefin hydrogenation is highly desirable. This helps minimize octane number loss as well as avoid excessive consumption of hydrogen. So far, much effort has been made to improve the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) selectivity for the conventional CoMo/Al2O3 catalysts by incorporating potassium [2–5] or potassium and phosphorus [6], coking pretreatment [7], using binary supports [8] and tailoring the properties of alumina support [9]. It has also been reported that the HDS/HYD selectivity is closely related to the morphology of MoS2 in the HDS of gasoline. Bao et al. proposed that the HDS selectivity could be adjusted by the stacking number, and CoMo/Al2O3 catalyst with a compromise between the dispersion and stacking showed the highest HDS selectivity [6,10]. In addition, other researchers also put forward that the HDS selectivity could be tuned by the slab length of MoS2 and catalyst with longer MoS2 slabs exhibited higher HDS selectivity [11–14]. These results indicated the relation between the HDS selectivity and the morphology of MoS2 in FCC gasoline upgrading is still under debate. In order to clarify this question, (Co)MoS2 catalysts with controllable morphology need to be synthesized. More importantly, unsupported catalysts were investigated in this work to eliminate the influence of support [8,9] and study the intrinsic properties. Various methods have been developed for preparing nanocrystalline MoS2, including thermal decomposition of thiosalts [15,16], solution reactions [17,18] and hydrothermal method [19–22]. Among them, hydrothermal method is one of the desirable approach which allows us to obtain MoS2 with original and controlled morphology [20]. In our previous work, the MoS2 catalysts were prepared under different S/Mo source ratios and MoS2 ± x catalysts with similar stacking numbers were obtained [23]. Moreover, we found that the Co/MoS2 ± x catalysts prepared under high S/Mo source ratios showed lower HDS selectivity due to the formation of more defects which cut the longer MoS2 slabs into more small pieces and producing more corner sites. However, these defect sites caused by non-stoichiometry sulfur are not stable thermodynamically and would disappear as the reaction moved on [24]. Thus, the main object of this work is to prepare (Co)MoS2 catalysts with controllable morphology and further study the morphology-performance relation, which is an important factor for enhancing the HDS/HYD selectivity in the HDS of FCC gasoline. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All Chemicals were of analytical reagent grade and used as received without further purification. The commercial MoS2 was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The MoS2 catalysts were prepared by a simple one-pot hydrothermal method. Typically, 4 mmol (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and 112 mmol CS(NH2)2 with a Mo to S ratio of 4 were dissolved in 140 mL deionized water under vigorous stirring to form a homogeneous solution. Without H+ addition, the pH value of the solution is about 5.3. The hydrochloric acid was added to adjust the pH value. Then the mixed solution was transferred into a 200 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was kept in an oven at 220 °C for 18 h. The products were washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times and finally dried at 60 °C under vacuum. The obtained catalysts were referred to as “MoS2-x”, where x indicates the pH value in the preparation process. The Co-promoted catalysts were prepared by impregnating the as-prepared MoS2 with Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O solution and dried at 60 °C under vacuum. The ratio of Co/(Co + Mo) is 0.3 in all Co-promoted samples. The samples were referred to as “Co/MoS2-x”, where x represents the pH value in the preparation process. To prepare the MoS2 with different precursors, 1.4496 g MoO3 and 9.0638 g Na2S·9H2O were firstly dissolved in 80 mL deionized water. Then 11.5 mL of 4 M HCl solution was slowly added, after which the solution was transferred into a 150 mL stainless steel autoclave. The hydrothermal reaction was kept in a muffle furnace at 320 °C for 2 h [25]. The product was washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times to remove the Na+ completely, and finally dried at 60 °C under vacuum. The obtained catalyst was denoted as MoS2-320-MoO3. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterization was carried out on a Rigaku D/Max-2500/PC powder diffractometer operating at 40 kV and 200 mA with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) in the 2θ range of 5 to 80° at a speed of 5°/min. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurement was performed on a Quantachrome Instruments by physisorption of nitrogen at 77 K. The samples were degassed at 300 °C for 6 h before experiments. The specific surface areas of the samples were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method with linear region in the P/P0 range of 0.05-0.30. The HRTEM images of the samples were taken on a Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin (FEI Company) device with an accelerating voltage of 300 kV. The SEM images of the samples were obtained on a Hitachi S5500 electron microscope. Raman spectroscopy was performed on a Renishaw inVia Raman instrument with a 532 nm excitation laser at a power of 0.03 mW. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) characterizations were performed on a home-made GC-TPR apparatus. The samples (10 mg) were pretreated in Argon at 130 °C for 1 h. Next, the Ar flow was switched to a 5% H2/Ar flow (50 mL/min), and the catalyst samples were heated to 650 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The H2 consumption was determined by Agilent 7890 gas chromatograph with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements of the samples were carried out using a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer equipped with a (150 W) Al Kα monochromatic source (hυ = 1486.6 eV). The calibration has been made with the C 1s peak at 284.6 eV and the corresponding spectra were fitted by Gaussian-Lorentzian curves. It should be noted that the MoS2 samples were analyzed without any treatment for all the characterizations, while the Co-promoted samples were sulfided in situ in a mixture of 10% H2S/H2 at 400 °C for 2 h and then stored in argon atmosphere before analysis. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation The catalytic tests for the selective HDS reaction of FCC gasoline were carried out on a high-pressure fixed-bed continuous flow microreactor. Two different real full-range FCC gasoline, feed A and feed B were used as feedstock in this work (detailed properties see Tables S1 and S2). The feed B was used in the Section 3.2 for catalyst evaluation because the feed A was used up. Prior to the reaction, 0.5 g catalysts with particle size of 20–40 mesh were sulfided in situ in a mixture of H2S/H2 (10% Vol. H2S) at 200 °C for 2 h for the non-promoted MoS2 samples to eliminate any oxidization that may occur [26]. For the Co-promoted MoS2 samples, the sulfidation was carried out at 400 °C for 2 h. After a stabilization period of 14 h, the reaction products were collected and analyzed. The total sulfur content in the feed and products were determined by a sulfur analyzer (Antek Instruments). The hydrocarbon compositions of the feedstock and products were analyzed with an Agilent 6890N gas chromatograph with a HP-PONA capillary column (50 m × 0.200 mm). Finally, the HDS activity (HDS%), hydrogenation activity of olefins (HYD%) and the selectivity factor (SF) were calculated as follows [10,27]: HDS % = S f − S p S f × 100 HYD % = O f − O p O f × 100 SF = ln ( S f / S p ) ln ( O f / O p ) Where the Sf and Sp represent the mass fractions of total sulfur content in the feedstocks and products, and Of and Op are the volume fractions of total olefin content in the feedstocks and products. 3 Results 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of (Co)MoS2 catalysts with different MoS2 crystallite size For the synthesis of MoS2 by hydrothermal method, factors such as temperature and pH value play a key role in the synthetic procedure. For example, H. P. Zhang et al. reported that the nucleation and crystal growth of nanocrystalline MoS2 can be greatly affected by the synthesis temperature and initial temperature [25]. P. W. Dunne et al. verified the importance of an acidic environment for the production of MoS3 [28]. It is also reported by W. Y. Wang et al. that the MoS2 catalysts prepared at the presence of H+ had a higher conversion in the HDO of p-cresol [29]. Consequently, according to previous reports, the reaction process for the synthesis of MoS2 using (NH4)6Mo7O24 and CS(NH2)2 as precursors by hydrothermal method was expressed as follows: (1) CS(NH2)2 + H2O → NH3 + CO2 + H2S (2) (NH4)6Mo7O24 + H2S → MoOxS4-x + NH3 + H2O (3) MoOxS4-x + H+ → MoS3 + H2O (4) MoS3  → Δ  MoS2 The overall reaction can be formulated as: (5) (NH4)6Mo7O24 + CS(NH2)2 + H+ + H2O → MoS2 + CO2 + NH3 From above analysis, the influence of H+ in the synthesis procedure is depicted in Scheme 1 . Without H+ addition, the reaction occurs in a moderate environment, resulting in a relative low supersaturation state. Fewer nuclei will be formed and the resulting MoS2 catalyst shows relative larger crystallites. However, after adding H+ and lowering the pH value, the reaction rate of step (3) is greatly enhanced as well as the supersaturation state. In such case, a large amount of nuclei are formed, leading to MoS2 catalyst with smaller crystallites. We also have prepared the MoS2 catalyst at the pH value of 14, however, no product was obtained. This phenomenon is consistent with the previous report [30], further demonstrating the importance of acidic circumstance in the nucleation step. Thus, the crystallite size of MoS2 catalysts can be easily tuned by modulating the pH value in the synthesis procedure. The crystal structure and phase purity of MoS2 catalysts prepared under different pH values are shown in Fig. 1 a. All the samples display peaks at 2θ = 14°, 33°, 39° and 59°, matching well the typical (0 0 2), (1 0 0), (1 0 3) and (1 1 0) planes of hexagonal 2H-MoS2 (JCPDS card no. 75-1539). No intermediate phase like MoO3 is observed, indicating the Mo precursor has been completely converted into MoS2 under the condition of 220 °C, 18 h, pH values from 0.9 to 5.3. The intensity of (0 0 2) peak is representative for the stacking of the slabs along the c axis. As shown in Fig. 1a, the (0 0 2) peaks broaden gradually when the pH value decreases, and the corresponding average stacking layers calculated by the Debye-Scherrer equation are 10.7, 6.8 and 3.5 layers for MoS2-5.3, MoS2-3.0 and MoS2-0.9 samples, which demonstrates a stacking diminution of the MoS2 catalysts [31]. Fig. 1b shows the XRD patterns of freshly sulfided Co-promoted samples, some other peaks at the 2θ = 30°, 31°, 48° and 52° are observed, matching well the (3 1 1), (2 2 2), (5 1 1) and (4 4 0) planes of Co9S8 (JCPDS card no. 65-6801). After sulfidation, the peak intensity is a little stronger than the non-promoted MoS2 catalysts, which indicates the high temperature sulfidation process promoted the growth of MoS2 crystallites. However, the decreasing trend of stacking number does not change for the Co-promoted samples. It is noteworthy that the peak intensity of Co9S8 increases gradually with the increased pH value and the corresponding Co9S8 phase content shows a significant increase from 23.7% (Co/MoS2-0.9) to 29.7% (Co/MoS2-5.3), in spite of the same Co/(Co + Mo) ratio in all the Co-promoted samples (Table 1 ). The physical structure of MoS2 catalysts prepared at different pH values and the corresponding freshly sulfided Co-promoted samples were measured by nitrogen physisorption. Fig. 2 shows that all the samples exhibit type IV isotherm with a H3 hysteresis loop which is characteristic of mesoporous materials with slit-shaped pores formed by plate-like particles [32]. Apparently, the pH value has a great effect on the textural properties of the samples. With the decrease of pH value, the specific surface areas and total pore volumes increase gradually as listed in Table 1. This suggests the low pH value has a positive effect on the specific area of MoS2 due to the decrease of particle size, in consistent with the results reported by Wang et al. [29]. After incorporation of Co, the deposition of Co9S8 on the surface of MoS2 leads to the decrease for both specific surface areas and pore volumes. However, the surface areas and pore volumes of Co-promoted samples also increase with decreased pH value. The morphology and structure of MoS2 catalysts were examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). As shown in Fig. 3 , all the MoS2 catalysts exhibit a 3D-flower like structure which consists of MoS2 nanosheets. This morphology is formed by the self-assembly of nanosheets in order to minimize the surface energy [33]. The detailed formation process of the MoS2 catalyst with 3D-flower like structure is depicted in the Fig. S1. However, the nanosheet shape of MoS2 catalysts become rougher as the pH value decreases. This is because the decreased pH value accelerated the hydrolysis of CS(NH2)2 and formation of MoOxS4-x and MoS3. In this case, the nucleation rate of MoS2 was greatly enhanced and the growth of along the (00l) direction was retarded, thus weakening the nanosheet structure. Fig. 4 presents the HRTEM images of MoS2-x samples. The MoS2 crystallites are marked by the red circles. The black thread-like fringes with a spacing about 0.65 nm correspond to the (0 0 2) basal planes of MoS2 slabs. It can be clearly observed the MoS2-0.9 catalyst (2–5 layers) exhibits a lower average layer numbers than the MoS2-3.0 catalyst (6–8 layers) and MoS2-5.3 catalyst (7–11 layers), in good agreement of the XRD and Raman results. Though the correct statistical treatment of the HRTEM images is difficult for unsupported MoS2-based catalysts because of stacks overlapping [20], it is obvious that the average slab length for the MoS2 catalysts shortens as the pH values decreased. Raman spectroscopy is extensively used to study the transition metal sulfides [34–37]. As shown in Fig. 5 , all the MoS2 and Co-promoted samples show two typical characteristic peaks corresponding to the in-plane E1 2g mode and out-of-plane A1g mode of the hexagonal MoS2 crystal, respectively. According to the previous studies, the stacking numbers can be identified by distinguishing the difference between (△κ = ν (A1g)-ν (E1 2g)) [35]. The △κ is about 26 cm−1 for MoS2-3.0, MoS2-5.3, Co/MoS2-3.0, and Co/MoS2-5.3, which agrees well with the bulk MoS2 previously reported [37]. While for samples of MoS2-0.9 and Co/MoS2-0.9, the △κ is around 24 cm−1 which means the decreased layer number. It also should be noted that a blue shift of A1g is observed only when the MoS2 layer number is decreased less than 6 [35,37]. The Raman spectra of the catalysts are in accordance of the XRD and HRTEM results. The XRD patterns showed the decreasing of the stacking with the decrease of the pH value. However, the HRTEM images revealed that the layer numbers for MoS2-0.9 is less than 6 while larger than 6 for MoS2-3.0 and MoS2-5.3 catalysts. XPS measurements were carried out to characterize the chemical state and composition of the catalysts. The XPS spectra of Mo 3d, S 2p and Co 2p levels of MoS2-0.9, MoS2-5.3, Co/MoS2-0.9 and Co/MoS2-5.3 are shown in Fig. 6 . It can be observed two characteristic peaks at 229.1 eV and 232.2 eV are attributed to the Mo 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 binding energies for a MoIV oxidation state (Fig. 6a), and the corresponding peaks for the S 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 orbitals of divalent sulfide ions (S2−) are observed at 161.9 and 163.1 eV (Fig. 6b) [25,38]. Importantly, no intermediate oxysulfide phase (MoOxSy, MoV) located at 230.2 ± 0.1 eV (MoV 3d5/2), 233.4 ± 0.1 eV (MoV 3d3/2) and Mo oxide phase (MoOx, MoVI) located at 232.2 ± 0.1 eV (MoVI 3d5/2), 235.3 ± 0.1 eV (MoVI 3d3/2) are examined, indicating the complete sulfidation of the Mo oxide precursors during the hydrothermal process [39]. The Co 2P3/2 in Fig. 6c are fitted well into three main peaks: the peak at the binding energy of 778.1 eV attributed to Co9S8 phase, another two peaks at 778.6 eV and 781.5 eV corresponded to the Co-Mo-S phase and the Co (II) oxide species. The remaining peaks of the envelopes are satellite lines of the corresponding Co species [40]. The quantitative analysis given in Table 2 showed that the ratio of Co atoms engaged in the Co-Mo-S phase of Co/MoS2-0.9 (74.0%) is higher than Co/MoS2-5.3 (63.9%) catalyst, in consistent with the HDS activity. As evidenced by the HRTEM results, the MoS2-0.9 has shorter slab length than MoS2-5.3, hence, thus providing more edge sites for location of the promoter Co and the formation of Co-Mo-S phase. TPR experiments have been carried out to characterize the different sulfur species and determine the total amount of the active sites. As shown in Fig. 7 , all the catalysts present the similar characteristic peaks which correspond to a strong well-resolved peak in the low temperature area (∼300 °C) and a low intensity broad area in the high temperature zone. According to the previous studies, the low temperature peak could be assigned to the weakly bonded sulfur species which could be removed by hydrogen to form the coordinative unsaturated sites (CUS) whereas the partial reduction of bulk phase occurred in the high temperature range [21,41]. For the non-promoted MoS2 catalysts, a strong peak is observed to be centered at about 314 °C. Besides, the relative areas increase as the pH value decreases and in agreement with their surface areas, suggesting the total active sites of the catalysts increase in the order: MoS2-5.3 < MoS2-3.0 < MoS2-0.9. After addition of Co, the Co/MoS2-x catalysts show low peak areas compared with the non-promoted MoS2 catalysts due to the loss of surface areas. However, compared with MoS2 catalysts, the incorporation of Co causes a downshift of the peak position from 314 °C to 296 °C. It is widely accepted that the accommodation of Co on the edge sites of MoS2 to form “Co-Mo-S” phase, thus optimizing the electronic structure of MoS2 and weakening the strength of MoS bond [42]. Similarly, the low temperature peak areas follows an order: Co/MoS2-0.9 > Co/MoS2-3.0 > Co/MoS2-5.3. It is concluded that the smaller slabs could provide more edge sites to accommodate Co atoms and form more “Co-Mo-S” phase, consistent with the results of XRD and XPS. The catalytic performance of the MoS2 catalysts prepared at different pH values and their corresponding Co-promoted catalysts in the HDS of FCC gasoline is presented in Table 3 . The HDS selectivity factor (SF) is defined to compare the selectivity of different catalysts conveniently. The catalyst with larger SF presents higher selectivity which is beneficial in the selective HDS of FCC gasoline. For the MoS2 catalysts, both the HDS activity and HYD activity of olefins decrease gradually when the pH value increases. However, their SFs increase in the order of MoS2-0.9 < MoS2-3.0 < MoS2-5.3. After the addition of Co, all the Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts show significantly improved HDS activity because of the weakened CS bond strength, while the HYD activity was inhibited. This is consistent with the results reported by R. Prins that the steep decrease in k HYD/k HDS for the addition of Co to the unsupported MoS2 catalyst [43]. The addition of Co to the edges of the MoS2 crystallites could block the coordinatively unsaturated Mo sites on the edges, and decrease the hydrogenation activity [44,45]. Hence, the HDS selectivity of Co-promoted samples is greatly improved compared with non-promoted MoS2 catalysts. Besides, the SFs of Co/MoS2-x catalysts also increase in the order of Co/MoS2-0.9 < Co/MoS2-3.0 < Co/MoS2-5.3. 3.2 Synthesis of MoS2 catalysts with similar stacking but different slab length The results of Section 3.1 showed that (Co)MoS2 catalysts with larger MoS2 crystallites exhibited higher HDS selectivity. However, both the stacking number and slab length are increased when the MoS2 crystallites grow larger. Therefore, MoS2 catalysts with similar stacking number but different slab length, or MoS2 catalysts with similar slab length but different stacking number need to be synthesized to investigate which factor is more important for improving the HDS selectivity. Through using the different precursors and changing the hydrothermal temperatures from 270 to 350 °C, we succeeded in preparing the MoS2-320-MoO3 catalyst which has similar stacking number but different slab length compared with MoS2-0.9 catalyst (XRD patterns of other samples prepared at 270, 300 and 350 °C are not shown). The XRD patterns of MoS2-320-MoO3 and MoS2-0.9 (Fig. 1a) show almost the same peak intensity of (002) planes, and the calculated stacking layers is 3.4 for MoS2-320-MoO3, which is close to the MoS2-0.9 (3.5 layers). Besides, it could be clearly seen in the HRTEM images (Fig. 4) that the stacking number of MoS2-320-MoO3 (2–4 layers) is close to MoS2-0.9, while the slab length is obviously shorter compared with MoS2-0.9 catalyst. The catalytic results listed in Table 4 show that both the HDS and HYD activity of MoS2-320-MoO3 is larger than MoS2-0.9 due to the shorter slab length and increased active sites. However, the HDS selectivity of MoS2-320-MoS2 is lower than MoS2-0.9 due to the increased extent of HYD activity is larger than the HDS activity. Besides, a commercial MoS2 with much longer slab length was also evaluated as comparison, and exhibited the highest HDS selectivity. 3.3 Relation between morphology and HDS selectivity From the Fig. 4, it is concluded that smaller MoS2 crystallites are obtained with the decrease of the pH value in the synthetic procedure. Hence, the MoS2 catalysts prepared in the low pH values show higher specific areas (Table 1) and more active sites (Fig. 7), thus leading to both higher HDS and HYD activities (Table 3). However, the HDS selectivity of the MoS2 catalysts is improved with the increase of the MoS2 crystallites although at the sacrifice of HDS activity. The addition of Co to the MoS2-x catalysts causes the decrease of the reduction temperature of the active sulfur species (Fig. 7), and greatly improves the HDS activity and inhibits the olefin HYD activity. Therefore, the HDS selectivity is greatly enhanced after Co-promotion. Besides, the HDS selectivity of Co/MoS2-x catalysts show the same trend with MoS2-x catalysts, indicating the morphology of MoS2 is the key factor to determine the HDS selectivity with or without Co promotion. Though the results here tell us (Co)MoS2 catalysts with larger MoS2 crystallites have higher HDS selectivity, we still could not figure out which factor is more important to influence the HDS selectivity because both the stacking number and slab length have increased when the MoS2 crystallites grow larger. Hence, the MoS2-320-MoO3 catalyst with similar stacking but shorter slab length compared with MoS2-0.9 was prepared to only check the influence of the slab length on the HDS selectivity of FCC gasoline (Scheme 1). The catalytic performance results listed in Table 4 obviously show the selectivity factor of MoS2-0.9 is larger than MoS2-320-MoO3 and smaller than the commercial MoS2, confirming the HDS selectivity is mainly influenced by the MoS2 slab length. Although the rim-edge model revealed the selectivity is related to the stacking height of MoS2, it should be noted that the authors also pointed out this model only applies to molecules with steric hindrance like DBT due to the adsorption mode [46]. Considering small molecules may not exhibit the rim-edge effect with the absence of steric hindrance, the corner-edge model is proposed to be more suitable for the HDS of gasoline. There are two different active sites on the MoS2 particles, the corner sites and edge sites. A. Wambeke et al. reported the isoprene hydrogenation occurs on the three coordinatively-unsaturated molybdenum sites of the MoS2 slabs and indicated the HYD reactions take place on more coordinatively-unsaturated sites than HDS [47]. Besides, according to the DFT computation results reported by X. D. Wen et al., the corner sites are more favored thermodynamically for hydrogen adsorption and formation of coordinatively-unsaturated sites than the edge sites [48]. Hence, the coordinative unsaturation degree is higher at corner sites than at the edge sites, resulting in higher HYD activity at the corner sites. Consequently, (Co)MoS2 catalysts with longer slab length, that is, the higher edge/corner ratios, exhibit higher HDS selectivity (Scheme 2 ). 4 Conclusions A series of unsupported MoS2 catalysts with controlled morphologies were synthesized by the hydrothermal method. The morphology tuning of MoS2 particles was realized by adjusting the pH values in the hydrothermal system which resulted in different nucleation rates. At lower pH values, the nucleation rate was greatly enhanced, producing MoS2 catalysts with smaller crystallites. The results show that the (Co)MoS2 catalysts with larger MoS2 crystallites exhibit higher HDS selectivity. In addition, the MoS2 catalysts with similar stacking but different slab length were also prepared using different precursors. Consequently, the MoS2 catalyst with longer slab length shows an improved HDS selectivity. These results further confirm the HDS selectivity for gasoline is mainly influenced by the slab length of MoS2 particles, and (Co)MoS2 catalysts with longer MoS2 slabs which have higher edge/corner ratios exhibit higher HDS selectivity. Acknowledgments This work was financially supported by Haldor Topsøe A/S company and the United Funds of NSFC-Liaoning (No. U1508205). Dr. Michael Brorson of Haldor Topsøe A/S is gratefully acknowledged for fruitful discussion. coredata.dc:description: The morphology-performance relation is of great importance for designing a catalyst with high performance in the selective hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) gasoline. Herein, we report a simple one-pot hydrothermal method to prepare the unsupported MoS2 catalysts with controlled morphology by adjusting the pH values and using different precursors. It is found that smaller MoS2 crystallites are produced when the pH value decreases in the synthetic process. With the increased MoS2 crystallite size, the HDS selectivity factor (SF) increases from 1.46 to 1.52 for non-promoted MoS2 catalysts, and from 13.96 to 19.69 for Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts. On the other hand, for MoS2 catalysts with similar stacking, the MoS2 with longer slab length exhibits improved HDS selectivity (SF from 2.90 to 2.99). These results confirm that the slab length instead of the stacking for MoS2 particles is more important to influence the HDS selectivity. Due to the fact that the corner sites could catalyze both HDS and HYD reactions while edge sites only catalyze the HDS reaction, thus increasing the edge/corner ratio by preparing (Co)MoS2 catalysts with longer MoS2 slab length is an efficient way to improve the selectivity in the selective HDS of FCC gasoline.
coredata.dc:title: Morphology-performance relation of (Co)MoS2 catalysts in the hydrodesulfurization of FCC gasoline
